bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Henry Rose Carter, March 19, 1917

div1.p: Gorgas discusses yellow fever theories and the possibility of war with Germany.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Henry Rose Carter, March 19, 1917
div1.opener:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
WASHINGTON.
March 19, 1917.
Dr. Henry R. Carter,
U. S. Marine Hospital,
Baltimore, Maryland.
My dear Carter:
div1.p:
I have just finished your manuscript and today
forwarded it to Dr. Lyster, as you directed. The article,
it seems to me, is excellent and I have no criticism to make.
You know that I am not inclined to accept the idea that
yellow fever can be kept up indefinitely by children. It is
rather an illogical position, but the theory that it can be
kept up by children does not seem to me to agree with the facts.
I am surprised to see in La Roche that he looks upon yellow
fever, so far as the fever is concerned, as a disease of one
exascerbation. His 20th chapter is entirely devoted to this
subject. All through his book he uses the expression: 'first,
second, and third, stage, subject of calm, etc.', but he is re-
ferring to the symptomology altogether. I am inclined to agree
with him entirely in his description of the disease, bearing in
mind this fact that he does not include the fever, i.e., temperature,
as having first, second, and third, stage.

Things look very war-like this morning. Are you prepared to
go after a German submarine? I am quite sure that Guiteras is
just boiling over to tackle one.
With kindest regards, I remain yours
